awd_titl_txt: Replication of G-quadruplex DNA by translesion polymerases
awd_abstract_narration:
DNA replication is a complex and perilous undertaking for cells because the risk of damage is greatest when the double helix is unwound for copying. Adding to this complexity is the fact that some DNA sequences tend to be more difficult to replicate accurately than others. Notable among these natural barriers to faithful replication are sequence motifs that adopt non-canonical structures such as G-quadruplex (G4) DNA. Failure to maintain evolutionarily conserved G4 motifs leads to genetic and epigenetic instability that is associated with chromosomal damage, cellular dysfunction, neurological diseases, and cancer. While it is known that special processing is required to maintain G4 integrity, the precise molecular mechanisms and cellular responses involved remain important areas of research. This project will investigate the role of a polymerase called Rev1 in copying and repairing G4 DNA. Successful completion of the project will provide new knowledge on the bypass of such replication barriers, a fundamental requirement for all living systems. The project will also support graduate student training at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences (UAMS), undergraduate trainees at Hendrix College, and mentoring of high-school students in Arkansas through outreach programs housed at UAMS. 

The major goal of the project is to test the hypothesis that Rev1, an enzyme with an unusual mechanism of action, functions to disrupt G4 structures, recruit other enzymes to sites of G4-induced replication stress, and maintain genetic/epigenetic integrity during replication of G4 motifs. The research will employ biophysical and biochemical approaches, including transient kinetics and proteomics, as well as cell-based assays to study key aspects of Rev1 activity that likely facilitate G4 replication and maintenance of the surrounding chromatin landscape. The outcomes will improve models of DNA replication and provide mechanistic insights into DNA processing pathways that have evolved to maintain important structural features of eukaryotic genomes.

This project is jointly funded by the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this project was to study how specialized enzymes help organisms copy guanine-rich regions of their genome capable of forming four-stranded G-quadruplex (or G4) DNA. G4 structures form when four guanines interact and adopt a planar quartet (or tetrad), which can then stack on other G-quartets to produce a nucleic acid structure with interesting physico-chemical properties and increasingly appreciated biological functions. Despite their biological utility, aberrant formation of G4 structures during cell division can impair DNA synthesis. The focus of the research supported by this award was primarily on the G4-related activities of an enzyme called Rev1, a DNA polymerase conserved from single-celled eukaryotes through mammals. During the award period, we discovered new mechanistic features of Rev1 that may contribute to G4 replication in some organisms, elucidating both biochemical and cellular properties that influence G4 maintenance. Five research articles and a Methods in Enzymology volume were a direct outcome of the award with another three publications from collaborations. Key research outcomes included:

1. We discovered that vertebrate forms of Rev1 bound more tightly to DNA when a G4 structure was present. Using purified forms of Rev1 from different organisms, we found that the G4 selective properties of Rev1 were most strongly observed in vertebrate forms of the enzyme. Rev1 from yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) and leishmania (Leishmania donovani) exhibited much less robust G4 binding and diminished ability to disrupt G-tetrads compared to human Rev1 and Rev1 from zebrafish (Danio rerio). These findings have implications for how Rev1 might fulfill taxa-specific physiological functions related to maintenance of G4 and other non-B DNA structures.

2. We identified parts of human Rev1 that are important for selective recognition of G4. Mutation of either the N-digit sub-domain or the insert-2 motif of human Rev1 diminished the affinity for G4 DNA substrates, with a more pronounced impact related to mutation of insert-2. The parts of human Rev1 that help produce strong binding to G4 DNA were also determined to be important for partial disruption of the guanine tetrads. We went on to discover that vertebrate Rev1 can stimulate DNA synthesis across the entirety of G4 motifs by another polymerase called pol kappa. The stimulation of G4 translesion synthesis by pol kappa was only observed when we tested forms of Rev1 that were able bind to and disrupt the G4 structure. This feature of Rev1 activity has important implications for how the enzyme may help keep the DNA synthesis machinery active and engaged when copying these key genomic sequences.

3. The impact of Rev1 on mutagenesis near G4 motifs was analyzed using a mutagenesis assay. We found that genetic deletion of Rev1 in human cells resulted in a 200-fold increase in the mutation frequency near G4 motifs positioned on the lagging strand, an effect that was increased another 3-4x when cells were treated with a chemical stabilizer of G4s called pyridostatin. The position of the guanine-rich motif in either the leading or lagging strand was found to make a difference in Rev1-dependent effects on mutation frequency near G4 sites, with the fork relying more heavily on Rev1 for accurate replication when G4 was enountered in the leading strand.

4. Just like other replication proteins, Rev1 does not function alone in cells. Using a technique called isolation of proteins on nascent DNA (iPOND) coupled with mass spectrometry, we discovered new connections between Rev1 and other G4 replication proteins. Ongoing experiments to determine the physical and functional relationships between Rev1 and the new interactors will help fill gaps in models of G4 DNA replication.

In addition to refining models describing how translesion synthesis contributes to DNA replication at G4 sites, our work is significant because Rev1 and its associated factors can promote tolerance of DNA damage and therapy resistance in cancer. The work performed during this award could also have an impact on our understanding of targeted hypermutation and activation of oncogenes.

This award has had a tremendous impact on research training opportunities in Arkansas. In total, this award supported 35 trainees - two research instructors, 12 graduate students (2 laboratory members and ten rotation students), one MD/PhD student (rotation), 11 undergraduate students, and nine high school students. Together, these students have given >50 presentations at local regional, and national scientific meetings and won 14 presentation awards. Of the 35 total trainees, 12 (~35%) were listed as co-author on peer-reviewed research articles with additional publications forthcoming that will increase the percentage of trainees with authorship. All trainees participated in professional development activities. The award supported development of a new course for graduate students at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences called Genome Dynamics focused on advanced concepts in genomic/epigenomic maintenance and an undergraduate course at Hendrix College called Biological Physics with data analysis and modeling as part of the course work.
